The cultural legacy of two decades of American occupation in Afghanistan has been harder to stamp out than the more obvious vestiges of the U.S. nation-building effort. In Kabul, snooker halls, video game dens, coffee shops, and restaurants are evidence of the Western influence that has become a part of the city's culture. Since the Taliban toppled the Western-backed government in 2001, Kabul's population has nearly doubled to five million people. Western culture is visible in the clothing, technology, and sports academies that have become a part of everyday life. Young people in particular have embraced the new culture, finding solace in the cafes, bookstores, and restaurants that offer a respite from the sometimes-dismal reality of the country.

  1. The Taliban have erased most obvious vestiges of the U.S. nation-building effort in Afghanistan, but the cultural legacy of two decades of American occupation has been harder to stamp out.
  2. Western influences remain in Kabul, such as snooker clubs, video game dens, coffee shops, and restaurants.
  3. Kabul's population has nearly doubled since 2001, with many new businesses catering to the nouveau riche.
  4. Young people in Kabul have embraced Western culture, such as wearing jeans, playing video games, and listening to Western music.
